text:
[Cites 
7
, Cited by 
0
]

Madhya Pradesh High Court

Govind vs The State Of Madhya Pradesh on 25 April, 2024

Author: 
Rohit Arya

Bench: 
Rohit Arya

 1
 IN THE HIGH COURT OF MADHYA PRADESH
 AT GWALIOR
 CRA No. 4730 of 2024
 (GOVIND Vs THE STATE OF MADHYA PRADESH)

 Dated : 25-04-2024
 Shri D.S. Rajawat - Advocate for the appellant.

 Shri Rajesh Shukla - Additional Advocate General for respondent/State.

 Heard on IA No.7450 of 2024, first application under 
Section 389(1)

 Cr.P.C. for suspension of sentence and grant of bail moved on behalf of
 appellant- Govind.

 Present appellant stood convicted under 
Section 376(1)
 IPC read with
 
Section 3(2)(va)
 of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of
 Atrocities) Act and under Section 506 Part II read with 
Section 3(2)(va)
 of
 Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act and
 sentenced to undergo imprisonment for life with a fine of Rs.5,000/- and two
 years' RI with a fine of Rs.2,000/- with default stipulations vide judgment of
 conviction and order of sentence dated 05.03.2024 passed by Special Judge
 [
Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 1989
],
 District Guna (M.P.) in SC ATR No.01/2019.

 Appellant -Govind so far has suffered incarceration of 06 months, as
 transpired during the course of hearing.

 A s per prosecution story, victim, at Police Station Cantt, got written
 Dehati Nalisi Ex.P-1 to the effect that on 12.09.2017 at about 04.40 pm when
 she had gone to her field to fetch maize, at that time accused/appellant Govind
 Meena of Veerpur came from behind and held her in arms. When she tried to
 escape, accused pushed her on the ground and pointing katta (country made
 pistol) to her threatened for dire consequences if she screamed. Whereafter, the

Signature Not Verified

Signed by: PAWAN

DHARKAR

Signing time: 4/25/2024

7:17:35 PM

 2

 accused committed rape upon the prosecutrix and fled away therefrom after
 giving threat in case she reported the matter. On the basis of such Dehati Nalisi,
 FIR was reduced in writing at Police Station Madhusudangarh at Crime
 No.48/2017 under 
Sections 376
, 
506
 IPC and under 
Sections 3(2)(va)
 and 
3(1)
 (w)(ii)
 of SC/ST Act and the investigation was set in motion. Upon completion
 of investigation including recording of statements, collection of evidence and
 necessary formalities, challan was filed. The Special Court on appreciation of
 evidence placed on record convicted and sentenced the present appellant as
 referred above.

 Learned counsel for the appellant while taking exception to the impugned

 judgment of conviction and order of sentence submits that the present appellant
 has falsely been implicated. The judgment of conviction and order of sentence
 is based on surmises and conjectures. There are contradictions and omissions
 in the statements of prosecution witnesses. Learned counsel submits that
 medical evidence does not support the story of prosecution as no definite
 opinion could be given by the doctor. He further submits that DNA report is
 negative. It is further submitted that the appeal being of 2024 is not likely to be
 decided in the near future. On these grounds, learned counsel submits that the
 present appellant may be extended the benefit of suspension of sentence and
 grant of bail.

 Per contra, learned Additional Advocate General, appearing on behalf of
 the respondent/State, while supporting the judgment impugned submits that no
 exception can be taken in the matter of suspension of sentence and grant of
 bail, regard being had to the nature and the gravity of offence found proved
 against the present appellant.

Signature Not Verified

 Upon hearing learned counsel for the parties, though this Court refrains

Signed by: PAWAN

DHARKAR

Signing time: 4/25/2024

7:17:35 PM

 3

 from commenting upon rival contentions so advanced touching merits of the
 case, regard being had to the fact that appeal which is of the year 2024 is not
 likely to be decided in the near future, in the obtaining facts and circumstances
 of the case, we are of the view that present appellant is entitled to the benefit of
 suspension of sentence and grant of bail.

 Accordingly, IA No.7450 of 2024 stands allowed and it is directed that
 the jail sentence of appellant Govind shall remain suspended during pendency
 of the present appeal and he shall be released on bail subject to verification of
 the factum of depositing the fine amount and on his furnishing a personal bond
 in the sum of Rs.2,00,000/- (Rupees Two Lacs only) with one solvent surety
 in the like amount to the satisfaction of the Trial Court.

 Appellant- Govind is directed to appear before the Registry of this Court
 first on 07.08.2024 and on other subsequent dates as may be fixed in this
 behalf.

 Accordingly, the said IA stands allowed and disposed of.
 Observations on facts, if any, are only for the purpose of deciding the
 instant I.A. and shall have no bearing on the merits of the appeal.

 Certified copy as per rules.

 (ROHIT ARYA) (RAJENDRA KUMAR VANI)
 JUDGE JUDGE

 pd

Signature Not Verified

Signed by: PAWAN

DHARKAR

Signing time: 4/25/2024

7:17:35 PM

paragraphs.text: Govind vs The State Of Madhya Pradesh on 25 April, 2024

1
 IN THE HIGH COURT OF MADHYA PRADESH
 AT GWALIOR
 CRA No. 4730 of 2024
 (GOVIND Vs THE STATE OF MADHYA PRADESH)

Dated : 25-04-2024
 Shri D.S. Rajawat - Advocate for the appellant.
Shri Rajesh Shukla - Additional Advocate General for respondent/State.

Heard on IA No.7450 of 2024, first application under 
Section 389(1)

Cr.P.C. for suspension of sentence and grant of bail moved on behalf of
 appellant- Govind.

Present appellant stood convicted under 
Section 376(1)
 IPC read with
 
Section 3(2)(va)
 of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of
 Atrocities) Act and under Section 506 Part II read with 
Section 3(2)(va)
 of
 Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act and
 sentenced to undergo imprisonment for life with a fine of Rs.5,000/- and two
 years' RI with a fine of Rs.2,000/- with default stipulations vide judgment of
 conviction and order of sentence dated 05.03.2024 passed by Special Judge
 [
Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 1989
],
 District Guna (M.P.) in SC ATR No.01/2019.

Appellant -Govind so far has suffered incarceration of 06 months, as
 transpired during the course of hearing.

A s per prosecution story, victim, at Police Station Cantt, got written
 Dehati Nalisi Ex.P-1 to the effect that on 12.09.2017 at about 04.40 pm when
 she had gone to her field to fetch maize, at that time accused/appellant Govind
 Meena of Veerpur came from behind and held her in arms. When she tried to
 escape, accused pushed her on the ground and pointing katta (country made
 pistol) to her threatened for dire consequences if she screamed. Whereafter, the

accused committed rape upon the prosecutrix and fled away therefrom after
 giving threat in case she reported the matter. On the basis of such Dehati Nalisi,
 FIR was reduced in writing at Police Station Madhusudangarh at Crime
 No.48/2017 under 
Sections 376
, 
506
 IPC and under 
Sections 3(2)(va)
 and 
3(1)
 (w)(ii)
 of SC/ST Act and the investigation was set in motion. Upon completion
 of investigation including recording of statements, collection of evidence and
 necessary formalities, challan was filed. The Special Court on appreciation of
 evidence placed on record convicted and sentenced the present appellant as
 referred above.
Learned counsel for the appellant while taking exception to the impugned

judgment of conviction and order of sentence submits that the present appellant
 has falsely been implicated. The judgment of conviction and order of sentence
 is based on surmises and conjectures. There are contradictions and omissions
 in the statements of prosecution witnesses. Learned counsel submits that
 medical evidence does not support the story of prosecution as no definite
 opinion could be given by the doctor. He further submits that DNA report is
 negative. It is further submitted that the appeal being of 2024 is not likely to be
 decided in the near future. On these grounds, learned counsel submits that the
 present appellant may be extended the benefit of suspension of sentence and
 grant of bail.

Per contra, learned Additional Advocate General, appearing on behalf of
 the respondent/State, while supporting the judgment impugned submits that no
 exception can be taken in the matter of suspension of sentence and grant of
 bail, regard being had to the nature and the gravity of offence found proved
 against the present appellant.
Upon hearing learned counsel for the parties, though this Court refrains

from commenting upon rival contentions so advanced touching merits of the
 case, regard being had to the fact that appeal which is of the year 2024 is not
 likely to be decided in the near future, in the obtaining facts and circumstances
 of the case, we are of the view that present appellant is entitled to the benefit of
 suspension of sentence and grant of bail.

Accordingly, IA No.7450 of 2024 stands allowed and it is directed that
 the jail sentence of appellant Govind shall remain suspended during pendency
 of the present appeal and he shall be released on bail subject to verification of
 the factum of depositing the fine amount and on his furnishing a personal bond
 in the sum of Rs.2,00,000/- (Rupees Two Lacs only) with one solvent surety
 in the like amount to the satisfaction of the Trial Court.

Appellant- Govind is directed to appear before the Registry of this Court
 first on 07.08.2024 and on other subsequent dates as may be fixed in this
 behalf.

Accordingly, the said IA stands allowed and disposed of.
 Observations on facts, if any, are only for the purpose of deciding the
 instant I.A. and shall have no bearing on the merits of the appeal.
